demo-user.summary: You’re a very strong applicant academically (4.0 UW/4.35 W, class rank #2, SAT 1570 with 800 Math, rigorous AP STEM). For Engineering, the most selective programs are still reaches for everyone, so I’m balancing top-tier “Extreme Reaches” with realistic “Target Match” options and a couple of high-likelihood “Safety” schools that still have solid engineering outcomes. Note: many universities do not offer Spring entry for first-year applicants in Engineering, so you should verify Spring 2027 availability for each school (or plan for Fall 2027 if needed).

recommendations.reasoning: World-leading engineering and CS; your SAT (1570/800M) and academic rigor are in range, but admission is extraordinarily competitive and heavily EC/impact-driven. Great fit if you can present distinctive technical depth/leadership beyond classes.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: ~$62k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action usually early Nov; Regular Action usually early Jan (confirm for your cycle)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid only (MIT meets full demonstrated need).

recommendations.reasoning: Elite engineering + entrepreneurship ecosystem in an urban-adjacent setting; your academics are strong, but Stanford is an extreme reach for all. Strong programming/leadership can help if you show tangible impact/projects.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: ~$65k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Restrictive Early Action usually early Nov; Regular Decision usually early Jan (confirm for your cycle)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid (no merit scholarships).

recommendations.reasoning: Top engineering reputation and recruiting; extremely competitive, especially for College of Engineering. As a CA resident with top stats and strong rigor, you’re a plausible contender but still a reach.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: CA resident: ~ $15k tuition/fees (total cost higher with housing); Nonresident higher
recommendations.application_deadline: UC application filing period typically Oct 1–Nov 30 (confirm for your cycle)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Berkeley financial aid and scholarships (many are need-based; some campus scholarships available).

recommendations.reasoning: Exceptional engineering/CS culture; your math/SAT profile fits well, but CMU (especially CS) is highly selective. Great if you want a tech-forward, project-heavy environment.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: ~$64k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Decision I usually early Nov; Regular Decision usually early Jan (confirm for your cycle)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid; limited merit scholarships.

recommendations.reasoning: Highly ranked engineering with broad majors and strong career outcomes; your stats are very competitive. Michigan can still be selective for out-of-state students, but this is a realistic “match/reach-leaning target.”
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Nonresident: ~ $60k+/yr total cost (tuition + housing/fees); check current COA
recommendations.application_deadline: EA usually early Nov; RD usually early Feb (confirm for your cycle)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid; limited merit for nonresidents (separate scholarship consideration varies by college).

recommendations.reasoning: Top public engineering with strong internships/co-ops; urban setting. Competitive for out-of-state, but your academics put you in a strong position. Good option if you want a tech campus with big recruiting pipelines.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state: ~ $32k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action/Regular deadlines vary by residency; confirm for your cycle
recommendations.scholarship_info: A few merit scholarships; many students use need-based aid + external scholarships.

recommendations.reasoning: Excellent engineering and CS-adjacent options with strong recruiting; your SAT math and rigor align well. Engineering admissions are competitive, but your profile is within a strong match range.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Nonresident: ~ $40k+ tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Priority deadline typically early Nov (varies by major/college); confirm for your cycle
recommendations.scholarship_info: Limited merit for nonresidents; check campus + college of engineering scholarship opportunities.

recommendations.reasoning: Strong engineering brand and outcomes at a comparatively better value; your stats are well above typical admits. Good “high-probability target,” especially if budget sensitivity increases.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Nonresident: ~ $28k–$33k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action usually Nov 1 (recommended for engineering); confirm for your cycle
recommendations.scholarship_info: Merit scholarships available; priority consideration often tied to Early Action.

recommendations.reasoning: Well-regarded College of Engineering with strong research and recruiting; for your stats, admission is likely (though specific engineering majors can be capacity constrained). Solid choice if you want a high-likelihood option with reputable outcomes.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Nonresident: ~ $40k+ tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Typically Nov 1 (EA) / mid-Jan (RD); confirm for your cycle
recommendations.scholarship_info: Merit/need-based scholarship options for nonresidents; check scholarship hub and FAFSA-based aid.

recommendations.reasoning: Large, well-established engineering programs with strong hands-on learning; admissions are very likely with your stats. Good safety that can also offer merit to high-achieving students, helping you stay within your $50–70k/yr budget target.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Nonresident: ~ $26k–$30k tuition/yr (total cost higher with housing/fees)
recommendations.application_deadline: Rolling admissions (apply earlier for scholarships/housing)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Automatic/competitive merit scholarships for first-year students; priority dates apply.

jay.summary: With a 3.9 UW / 4.3 W GPA and a 1570 SAT, you’re academically competitive for top engineering programs nationwide. Because engineering admissions can be more selective than overall university admissions (and some publics have limited merit aid for out-of-state students), this list balances highly selective “name-brand” engineering reaches with realistic targets and a couple of strong safeties—while keeping an eye on your $30k–$60k/year budget and your openness to location/vibe.

recommendations.reasoning: Top-tier engineering across all disciplines; even with excellent stats, MIT is a reach for everyone due to extremely low admit rates and holistic review. Strong fit if you want maximum academic rigor and research intensity.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: $62k+/yr tuition (plus fees, housing, meals; total cost higher)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action: Nov 1 (typical) / Regular Action: early Jan (typical)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based financial aid (MIT does not offer merit scholarships).

recommendations.reasoning: Elite engineering plus strong optionality if you later pivot toward business/econ; extremely selective. Great for interdisciplinary exploration and entrepreneurship.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: $65k+/yr tuition (total cost higher)
recommendations.application_deadline: Restrictive Early Action: Nov 1 (typical) / Regular Decision: early Jan (typical)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid; no merit scholarships for undergrads.

recommendations.college_name: University of California, Berkeley (College of Engineering)
recommendations.reasoning: In-state advantage helps, but Berkeley Engineering is still highly selective; outstanding engineering reputation and strong recruiting. Note: UC campuses are test-blind, so your SAT won’t be considered for admission.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: CA resident tuition/fees ~ $15k/yr (total cost with housing/meals higher)
recommendations.application_deadline: UC application window typically Oct 1–Nov 30
recommendations.scholarship_info: Primarily need-based; limited campus scholarships. File FAFSA/CA Dream Act if eligible.

recommendations.college_name: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor (College of Engineering)
recommendations.reasoning: Excellent engineering with broad majors and strong career outcomes; your academics are in-range for competitive consideration, though OOS engineering remains selective. Good balance of prestige and opportunities.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state total cost often $70k+/yr (can exceed your budget without aid)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action: Nov 1 (typical) / Regular Decision: early Feb (typical)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Limited merit for out-of-state; explore College of Engineering scholarships and broader U-M aid resources.

recommendations.college_name: University of California, San Diego (Jacobs School of Engineering)
recommendations.reasoning: Strong engineering and research; typically a more attainable UC engineering option than Berkeley/UCLA while still being high quality. UC is test-blind (SAT not used).
recommendations.tuition_estimate: CA resident tuition/fees ~ $15k/yr (total cost with housing/meals higher)
recommendations.application_deadline: UC application window typically Oct 1–Nov 30
recommendations.scholarship_info: Need-based aid and some campus scholarships; check UCSD scholarship opportunities.

recommendations.college_name: University of California, Irvine (Henry Samueli School of Engineering)
recommendations.reasoning: Solid engineering outcomes and strong CA recruiting; generally a realistic match for high-stat CA students compared to the most selective UCs. UC is test-blind (SAT not used).
recommendations.tuition_estimate: CA resident tuition/fees ~ $15k/yr (total cost with housing/meals higher)
recommendations.application_deadline: UC application window typically Oct 1–Nov 30
recommendations.scholarship_info: Campus scholarships and need-based aid; review UCI scholarship portal and deadlines.

recommendations.reasoning: Well-regarded engineering with a classic big-campus experience; strong academics and recruiting. Often somewhat more attainable than the most selective engineering flagships, but still competitive.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state total cost often $60k+/yr (may be near/above your stated budget)
recommendations.application_deadline: Regular Decision typically early Jan (varies by year/round)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Merit scholarships are limited/competitive; check Wisc scholarship hub and engineering-specific awards.

recommendations.reasoning: Large, well-resourced engineering college with strong outcomes and many majors; typically a solid match for high-stat applicants, though engineering can be selective.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state total cost often $55k–$65k/yr (varies by year)
recommendations.application_deadline: Early Action typically Nov 15 / Regular Decision typically Jan 15 (varies by year)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Merit scholarships available; check VT scholarship and financial aid resources.

recommendations.college_name: Arizona State University (Fulton Schools of Engineering)
recommendations.reasoning: High-likelihood admission with your stats; very large engineering school with many pathways and strong industry connections. Often offers substantial merit for high SAT/GPA profiles, helping fit your $30k–$60k budget.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state tuition/fees ~ $35k/yr (total cost higher; merit may reduce)
recommendations.application_deadline: Rolling admission (priority dates vary by term/program)
recommendations.scholarship_info: ASU New American University (NAMU) merit scholarships are common for strong academics.

recommendations.reasoning: Likely admission with your academic profile; solid engineering options and merit awards that can make costs manageable within your budget range.
recommendations.tuition_estimate: Out-of-state tuition/fees ~ $38k/yr (total cost higher; merit may reduce)
recommendations.application_deadline: Rolling admission (priority dates vary)
recommendations.scholarship_info: Merit scholarships for nonresidents; check main scholarship grid/award criteria.
